title: How to Prepare Tomatillos

steps.headline: Peel 4 tomatillos.
steps.description: Take the ripe tomatillos and peel back the papery shell. You should easily be able to tug the shell away. Pull it off at the stem and discard the shell. Peel each of the tomatillos.

steps.headline: Rinse and cut each tomatillo into 4 pieces.
steps.description: Run each tomatillo under warm water for about 10 seconds to remove the sticky residue. Use a sharp knife to cut each tomatillo into 4 evenly-sized pieces and transfer them to a blender. If you don't have a blender, you can use a large food processor.

steps.headline: Place the onion, chile, cilantro, and salt in a blender with the tomatillos.
steps.description: Add 2 tablespoons (20 g) of diced white onion, 1 serrano chile, 8 sprigs of cilantro, and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt to the blender.

steps.headline: Pulse the ingredients until they're as smooth as you like.
steps.description: Put the lid on the blender and pulse the salsa several times. Keep pulsing the salsa until it's as smooth as you want it.

steps.headline: Taste and serve the raw tomatillo salsa.
steps.description: Remove the blender lid and pour the fresh salsa into a serving bowl. Taste the salsa and stir in more salt, if necessary. Serve the salsa with tortilla chips or grilled meat. Refrigerate the leftover salsa in an airtight container for 5 to 7 days. Keep in mind that it will lose its crunch the longer it's stored.

steps.headline: Peel and rinse 8 tomatillos.
steps.description: Pull off and discard the papery shells from the tomatillos. Run the tomatillos under warm water until the sticky residue is gone and set them on a cutting board. Always remove the papery shells since these will become tough and bitter if cooked.

steps.headline: Cut the tomatillos into 1/4 in (0.6 cm) thick slices.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to cut each tomatillo into even slices. Set the slices aside while you mix the breadcrumb coating.

steps.headline: Beat 3 large eggs.
steps.description: Crack the eggs into a shallow bowl or pie plate and use a whisk or fork to beat them. Set the bowl on a counter near your stove.

steps.headline: Mix the breadcrumbs, flour, salt, and cumin in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Measure 2 cups (250 g) of breadcrumbs, 1 cup (240 g) of flour, 1 teaspoon (2.5 g) ground cumin, and 2 teaspoons (11 g) of salt into another bowl. Stir the mixture together until the mixture is combined. Set the bowl on the counter near your stove.

steps.headline: Heat 1 cup (240 ml) of canola oil over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Pour the oil into a deep skillet and turn the burner to medium-high. Let it heat until it shimmers.

steps.headline: Dip the tomatillo slices in egg and breading.
steps.description: Take a slice of tomatillo and lower it into the beaten egg. Lift it up and set it in the bowl with the breadcrumb mixture. Coat the entire slice with the mixture and set it aside on a baking sheet while you coat the rest of the slices.

steps.headline: Fry the tomatillos for 2 to 4 minutes.
steps.description: Slowly lower each of the coated tomatillos into the hot oil in your skillet. They should be in a single layer. Fry the tomatillos over medium-high heat without moving them so they turn golden brown on the bottom. If your skillet is small, you'll need to fry the tomatillos in batches.

steps.headline: Flip and fry the tomatillos for 2 to 4 more minutes.
steps.description: Use long-handled tongs to carefully flip each tomatillo slice over and let them fry until they're completely browned and crisp.

steps.headline: Drain and serve the fried tomatillos.
steps.description: Lay paper towels on the serving plate and use tongs to transfer the fried tomatillos from the skillet to the paper towels. The paper towels will absorb the excess oil. Serve the fried tomatillos immediately. Avoid storing the fried tomatillos because they'll become soggy.

steps.headline: Turn on the broiler and peel 1 pound (450 g) of tomatillos.
steps.description: Pull off and discard the papery peel from each tomatillo. Move an oven rack so it's 3 to 4 in (7.5 to 10 cm) below the broiler's heating element.

steps.headline: Rinse the tomatillos and cut them in half.
steps.description: Run the tomatillos under warm water until the sticky residue is completely gone. Set the tomatillos on a cutting board and use a sharp knife to cut each 1 in half.

steps.headline: Toss the tomatillos with 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of oil on a baking sheet.
steps.description: Place the tomatillo halves on a rimmed baking sheet and drizzle the vegetable oil over them. Use your hands to toss the tomatillos a little so they're coated in the oil. Turn each tomatillo half so the skin side is facing up.

steps.headline: Place the peppers and garlic on the baking sheet with the tomatillos.
steps.description: Trim the stems from 2  jalapeños, 2 poblanos, and 2 serrano peppers. Cut each pepper in half lengthwise and remove the seeds from the poblanos. Put the peppers and 4 cloves of garlic on the baking sheet with the tomatillo halves. If you can't fit the peppers and tomatillos on the sheet in a single layer, you may need to use an extra baking sheet.

steps.headline: Broil the vegetables for 20 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet 3 to 4 in (7.5 to 10 cm) below the broiler. Broil the vegetables until the pepper skins become dark and charred in spots. Remove the sheet from the oven so the peppers and tomatillos can cool.

steps.headline: Transfer the vegetables to a blender.
steps.description: For a smoother sauce, consider peeling the roasted peppers. Put the peppers and tomatillos into a blender or food processor. Squeeze the roasted garlic out of their peels and put them in the blender.

steps.headline: Add the cilantro, cumin, chili powder, salt, and pepper and pulse the mixture.
steps.description: Measure 2 tablespoons (2 g) of chopped cilantro into the blender along with ½ tablespoon (4 g) of cumin, 1 tablespoon (8 g) of spicy chili powder, salt, and pepper to taste. Put the lid on the blender and pulse the sauce ingredients until they're combined.

steps.headline: Blend in 2 cups (470 ml) of chicken broth.
steps.description: Remove the lid or open the spout and pour in the broth. Put the lid back on or close the spout and blend the sauce until it's completely smooth.

steps.headline: Use the tomatillo enchilada sauce in your favorite Mexican meal.
steps.description: Make your favorite enchilada recipe or heat the enchilada sauce and set it out as a condiment for other Mexican foods. Store the leftover enchilada sauce in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 5 to 7 days.

If you don't have a blender, you can use a large food processor. Place the onion, chile, cilantro, and salt in a blender with the tomatillos. Add 2 tablespoons (20 g) of diced white onion, 1 serrano chile, 8 sprigs of cilantro, and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt to the blender. Pulse the ingredients until they're as smooth as you like. Put the lid on the blender and pulse the salsa several times. Keep pulsing the salsa until it's as smooth as you want it. Taste and serve the raw tomatillo salsa. Remove the blender lid and pour the fresh salsa into a serving bowl. Taste the salsa and stir in more salt, if necessary. Serve the salsa with tortilla chips or grilled meat. Refrigerate the leftover salsa in an airtight container for 5 to 7 days. Keep in mind that it will lose its crunch the longer it's stored. Making Fried Tomatillos Peel and rinse 8 tomatillos. Set the slices aside while you mix the breadcrumb coating. Beat 3 large eggs. Crack the eggs into a shallow bowl or pie plate and use a whisk or fork to beat them. Set the bowl on a counter near your stove. Mix the breadcrumbs, flour, salt, and cumin in a separate bowl. Measure 2 cups (250 g) of breadcrumbs, 1 cup (240 g) of flour, 1 teaspoon (2.5 g) ground cumin, and 2 teaspoons (11 g) of salt into another bowl. Stir the mixture together until the mixture is combined. Set the bowl on the counter near your stove. Heat 1 cup (240 ml) of canola oil over medium-high heat. Pour the oil into a deep skillet and turn the burner to medium-high. Let it heat until it shimmers. Dip the tomatillo slices in egg and breading. Take a slice of tomatillo and lower it into the beaten egg. Lift it up and set it in the bowl with the breadcrumb mixture. Coat the entire slice with the mixture and set it aside on a baking sheet while you coat the rest of the slices. Fry the tomatillos for 2 to 4 minutes. Slowly lower each of the coated tomatillos into the hot oil in your skillet. They should be in a single layer. Fry the tomatillos over medium-high heat without moving them so they turn golden brown on the bottom. If your skillet is small, you'll need to fry the tomatillos in batches. Flip and fry the tomatillos for 2 to 4 more minutes. Use long-handled tongs to carefully flip each tomatillo slice over and let them fry until they're completely browned and crisp. Drain and serve the fried tomatillos. Lay paper towels on the serving plate and use tongs to transfer the fried tomatillos from the skillet to the paper towels. The paper towels will absorb the excess oil. Serve the fried tomatillos immediately. Avoid storing the fried tomatillos because they'll become soggy. Making Roasted Tomatillo Enchilada Sauce Turn on the broiler and peel 1 pound (450 g) of tomatillos. Pull off and discard the papery peel from each tomatillo. Move an oven rack so it's 3 to 4 in (7.5 to 10 cm) below the broiler's heating element. Rinse the tomatillos and cut them in half. Run the tomatillos under warm water until the sticky residue is completely gone. Set the tomatillos on a cutting board and use a sharp knife to cut each 1 in half. Toss the tomatillos with 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of oil on a baking sheet. Place the tomatillo halves on a rimmed baking sheet and drizzle the vegetable oil over them. Use your hands to toss the tomatillos a little so they're coated in the oil. Turn each tomatillo half so the skin side is facing up. Place the peppers and garlic on the baking sheet with the tomatillos. Trim the stems from 2  jalapeños, 2 poblanos, and 2 serrano peppers. Cut each pepper in half lengthwise and remove the seeds from the poblanos. Put the peppers and 4 cloves of garlic on the baking sheet with the tomatillo halves. If you can't fit the peppers and tomatillos on the sheet in a single layer, you may need to use an extra baking sheet. Broil the vegetables for 20 to 30 minutes. Place the baking sheet 3 to 4 in (7.5 to 10 cm) below the broiler. Broil the vegetables until the pepper skins become dark and charred in spots. Remove the sheet from the oven so the peppers and tomatillos can cool. Transfer the vegetables to a blender. For a smoother sauce, consider peeling the roasted peppers. Put the peppers and tomatillos into a blender or food processor. Squeeze the roasted garlic out of their peels and put them in the blender. Add the cilantro, cumin, chili powder, salt, and pepper and pulse the mixture. Measure 2 tablespoons (2 g) of chopped cilantro into the blender along with ½ tablespoon (4 g) of cumin, 1 tablespoon (8 g) of spicy chili powder, salt, and pepper to taste. Put the lid on the blender and pulse the sauce ingredients until they're combined. Blend in 2 cups (470 ml) of chicken broth. Remove the lid or open the spout and pour in the broth. Put the lid back on or close the spout and blend the sauce until it's completely smooth. Use the tomatillo enchilada sauce in your favorite Mexican meal. Make your favorite enchilada recipe or heat the enchilada sauce and set it out as a condiment for other Mexican foods. Store the leftover enchilada sauce in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 5 to 7 days.
